segments.text: It's the 24th of July, 1987.
We're at the Hyatt Hotel in Kansas City, Missouri.
And I'm here with Ellen Black from the faculty of the University of Kansas at Lawrence.
Ellen, would you tell us a little bit about your background?
Well, I grew up in the Boston area.
And I went to Harvard and majored in philosophy.
And after graduation, I started out as a newspaper reporter and worked at that for six years, starting out with a very small weekly paper and kept changing jobs and gradually moved up.
And after a couple of years, I became a sports editor of a small daily paper in Middletown, New York.
And then in 1955, I decided to go to California
And I got a job as sports editor of the Hayward paper, Hayward, California, which was only about 15,000 people at that time.
I guess it's over 100,000 today.
I think so.
Yeah.
That wasn't a very good job, and I only kept that for a number of months.
But then I was fortunate enough to get a good job with the San Jose Mercury, which is quite a large, large paper.
And I worked on it about two and a half years.
During that time I became rather disillusioned with reporting and at the same time became quite interested in city planning.
City planning in the Bay Area then was a popular topic.
Yeah, well it was a time of tremendous growth and a lot of problems coming from it and as a general reporter, which I was for the Mercury, about
About half of the news is police news, and about half is local government.
And 2% or 3% fit it in for odd things.
And I would say at least half of the local government news had something to do with planning or land use development.
I was technically interested in Fremont, where I started and lived for about a year.
And they decided to employ a couple of reporters there because they're just incorporated as a city.
And one of the first things that city council did was to hire a planning consultant to draw a comprehensive plan for Fremont.
And that consultant was Harold Wise, and quite a complicated story that happened that's not really relevant here, but it was quite an interesting plan, and a lot of it was carried out.
Who was the planning director?
Well, they did a nationwide search.
They had a search for a city manager first, and then for the planning director, and the person who was hired was named Dick Wilkinson, who had done his master's degree at Oklahoma.
And they later on went to Redwood City, I think.
I don't know what happened to him.
I lost track of him.
Who took over after Dick?
Do you know?
I think Roy Potter.
Roy Potter.
He's in San Diego now.
Yeah, I've lost track of most of those California people.
But I used to know a lot of the planning directors around the Bay Area.
After that, I moved to the Peninsula office and mostly covered Mountain View and Los Gatos.
Los Altos.
Los Altos.
Right.
Lawrence Livingston was a consultant in Los Altos.
I got to know him a bit.
Do you know Bill Spangle?

uh only very slightly you know there was let's say there were two directors in mountain view uh i think the first one was named george brenner and then he was succeeded by dick gamble and again i'm not sure they're probably still in california somewhere dick gamble's dead is that right he worked for the uh bunny department of san francisco and
I met him when we were both employed with Wilsey Hammond Blair in Foster City, but he died.
I didn't know that.
So along about the beginning of 1958, I decided I'd leave newspaper field and go to graduate school and get a master's degree in planning.
And so I applied to several schools, and I was
Really interested in going to Berkeley, and they accepted me, but they didn't offer me any financial aid.
After working all those years, you needed financial aid?
Reporters don't get paid very much.
Only in the Mercury, I was in a union job.
I mean, I started out with that $40 a week when I graduated from Harvard.
Boy.
And I gradually, when I...
Got into the mercury.
Overnight, my salary went up a lot.
But even so, I think at the time I left, I was only making a little over $5,000 a year.
So I really hadn't saved very much.
Well, I think I was offered a research assistantship by North Carolina, and I decided to go there because of that.
Although I think, if I recall, the amount was $1,800.
for the assistantship, which seemed like a lot of money at that time.
Well, they probably waived your tuition, too.
I got a reduction.
I think I got in-state tuition, which was fairly nominal.
Yeah.
But I didn't like it very much at North Carolina.
Part of the personal thing that I was research assistant to Peter Nash.
And he ran into some trouble in the middle of the year and had to resign from the faculty.
And he left at the end of that year.
What happened?
Well, Peter, that's quite a long story.
So you left North Carolina and then you?
I went out, I believe, at Christmas time on vacation and went and talked to Jack Kent.
to see if I could transfer.
And he agreed to give me full credits for the year at North Carolina.
So in June, I packed up and left Chapel Hill.
And I did an internship in San Jose, Santa Clara County, in that summer.
And then I did my second year at Berkeley.
That was with Michael Antonacci in Santa Clara County?
No.
No, he was the city planning director.
That's right.
He was with San Jose.
He was with Carl.
Belser.
Carl Belser's agency, right.
I knew Carl quite well.
Well, I worked more with Roy Cameron, who later became the director.
Now, Carl was hot on agricultural zoning at that time.
Yes, he was.
I really didn't have much to do with him.
Well, it was quite a big agency even then.
There were like 40 people in the planning center.
Yes, I think that they had the reputation of being one of the finest county planning departments in the United States.
That's right.
So after your internship in the summer, then?
Then I did my second year at Berkeley.
And you're interested in Jack Kent, I think.
Well, anyone that you can stand on that, particularly.
Well, Jack sort of picked me out from the students and got me interested in the general plan.
And I agreed to find out to write a master's thesis on it
It was after I'd been there about three months or so.
And at the time, there was an option between taking a comprehensive exam and doing a thesis.
And everybody took the exam, but I decided to do a thesis.
When I was there, they didn't have the option.
It changed shortly after that.
You had to do a thesis.
Yeah.
Well, I read your thesis at the time.
I remember that.
Oh, you did?
Didn't you do it under Kenyon?
I thought the general plan was on somewhere, wasn't it?
Yes, it was.
You needn't have read it, though.
I mean, there wasn't much to it.
It was the Metropolitan Open Space in the San Francisco Bay region.
All right.
Mm-hmm.
So Jack was- I know what happened.
What they did was there were so many people that weren't getting their degrees because they never finished their thesis.
Right.
that they opened it up for an option to take a comp exam.
So at least these people could get a degree to get out of there.
That's a universal problem in planning schools everywhere I've been.
Well, I think there were 20 that graduated my class.
I think 18 took the exam.
And two took the thesis.
And the other one besides me was Alan Blackman.
I don't think he ever finished.
Alan Blackman?
I don't think he ever got his degree.
So Jack was very insecure about his writing and was particularly interested in me because I had been a journalist and he was impressed with my writing.
So I finished my thesis in the summer
after the second year and got my degree.
Wait a minute, what was the topic?
It was called Functions of the Urban General Plan, I think.
Functions of the Urban General Plan.
What was the date then?
That was 1960.
I think I got my degree in October of 1960.
And then I took a job in Chicago with a transportation study there.
With CATS?
With CATS, Chicago Area Transportation Study.
And that started me in the transportation field, which has been my special area ever since.
That was purely accidental.
I never took a course in that at Berkeley.
I think I had one course, a required course, in traffic engineering at North Carolina.
I mostly wanted to do research.
I got quite interested in statistics.
And this agency was...
was known as a research-oriented agency.
Mel Weber had promoted it very much.
He was more research-oriented than anybody else at Berkeley at that time.
So I kind of moved into that, and the first few papers I did were fairly statistical, mathematical.
In the meantime, as John Kent pushed along on writing his book,
So I think he'd sort of been working on them for about 10 years, little by little.
10 years?
I think so.
He had different things.
He'd write papers, and then he'd put it aside.
This will be part of the book, and so forth.
But in the early 60s, he really kind of put it together.
And I don't know.
Maybe he took a sabbatical or something.
I'm not really sure.
But he asked me if I'd be co-author with him.
And I thought about it for a while, and I declined, because I really wasn't interested in the subject much anymore.
And so he went ahead on his own, and he got a publisher.
And he used to send me to some material to comment on, which I did.
I just noticed in my files that I had quite a few letters, long letters from him.
And however, what happened, you asked me on the phone, I guess, last week about did Kent steal my ideas and all.
And that really wouldn't be accurate.
The ideas basically were his.
And I think I suggested some refinements in some of them, some of which he accepted and then took into his own.
But they were fairly minor things.
What he did really was he stole my writing.
And when the book finally was completed and came out, it's divided into five chapters.
And two of the chapters essentially were copied out of my master's thesis.
Which were they?
I'd have to look at the book and see.
I forgot.
One of them does deal with the functions.
The other might be a...
Uses and characteristics?
I think that might be his.
He had that pretty well developed.
I kind of worked on a part of his thinking that he hadn't developed very much.
I think when he started, he had three functions, and I added two more.
I think one of them was education, I remember.
I think the other chapter he took was a kind of background chapter.
about the different forms of government and the role of city manager.
Now the things about the Standard City Enabling Act, that's all his.
Yeah, that was the second chapter.
Essentially what he did was he took my thesis and treated it as though it was his first draft.
And he'd make some changes and things, but there are lots of paragraphs that are word for word the same.
It's what we call plagiarism today.
We don't let students do it.
Exactly.
And you can be kicked out of Harvard for doing it.
Yes.
Well, that would be the first chapter then.
No, I'm not sure it's the first.
I'd have to look at it again.
I haven't looked at it for many years.
Well, it's the urban plan, the government, and the planning process or something like that, the first chapter.
Well, whatever.
Yeah.
So that, as I say, I didn't think there was much I could do about that since I was kind of nobody, and he was a very important person in the field and all.
But that kind of chilled our relationship, and I never really had much to do with him since then.
I didn't realize what he was going to do.
Yeah.
Too bad.
OK. Well, let's see.
I want to get back now.
So you were at Katz.
Yes, okay, so I worked there about three years, and then I got a Fulbright grant to study in the Netherlands as a student grant, not a faculty grant like we had or a scholar grant.
And I was at Delft at the technological school.
Then when I came back, I went to work in New York City for what was then called the Tri-State Transportation Commission.
And both of those translation studies were directed by Douglas Carroll.
And he had been director in Chicago, and he then moved to New York.
And I guess I was one of about five people that eventually moved from Chicago to New York with him.
So in between, I had a year in Europe.
So I worked there till 1968, and in 1967,
Paul Davidoff asked me to teach a class at Hunter College.
And he had recently become famous for advocacy planning and had been asked to start a program at Hunter.
He was a professor at Penn at the time.
He had written his famous articles.
I believe I met him at Penn when I was there.
Could be, yeah.
And when he was a student.
That could be, yeah.
Of course, he has a law degree, too, or he did have.
Of course, he's deceased now.
So they wanted a course in transportation planning.
And they were getting a lot of complaints from their students that their program wasn't practical.
It was very ideological, which of course it was.
And so he tried to hire some practitioners.
And so I taught an evening course in transportation planning.
And I enjoyed it very much.
I really got a kick out of that.
And so I decided to go into teaching.
And I knew I had to get a PhD to do that.
And I also had some consciousness of inadequacies in my background.
I didn't think I knew enough about economics.
I would go to conferences, and I wouldn't understand some of these papers that were given there.
So I applied to several schools again, and I decided to go to Cornell, largely because Barclay Jones was there.
I knew Barclay at Berkeley.
Well, I didn't really know him very well, because the year I was there, he was on sabbatical.
Oh.
And while he was in town, he was working with Steve Jacobs on their study of the historic preservation of San Francisco.
But he didn't teach any courses.
I think he taught a course for architecture students, but none for planning students.
So I only knew him slightly.
Then the other connection I had with him was Pierre Clavel, who had been in North Carolina with me, he and his wife.
And they had, in the meantime, gone up to Cornell.
He had gotten a PhD at Cornell.
So when I went to Cornell, he was a professor there.
And really, the main thing he had
I mean, I considered going back to Berkeley, too, and almost did that.
But I finally decided to go to Cornell.
Did you know John Reps at Cornell?
No, I didn't.
I never took a course from him.
Cornell faculty was divided into two factions, the traditionalists and the modernists.
And I was with the modernists.
And in fact, it came down, really, that it was kind of Reps against Barclay Jones.
Really?
I think there was a period, a couple of years, they didn't speak to each other, although I think their offices were adjacent.
Oh, dear.
I know both of them, and I admire both of them.
Well, yeah, they're both very talented people and all, but they have very different ideas about some things.
So, well, actually, while I was at, I guess I lived in Ithaca for four years.
And last year, I taught on the faculty.
I had a one-year appointment for a professor who was on leave.
And that year, actually, the department split into two separate departments.
And one of them that I was an instructor in was called Policy Planning and Regional Analysis.
And it was the quantitative one.
And Barclay Jones was the chairman of that.
He'd never been able to get to be chairman before.
because he had so many enemies in the faculty.
And the other one was called Urban Planning and Development.
It was pretty much a traditional land use planning program.
And Stuart Stein was the chair of that one.
Why did Barclay have so many enemies?
He's such a pleasant chap.
Well, Barclay's kind of a schemer.
Is he?
And he's always doing things behind the scenes.
Over the years, he's kind of built up his friends and his enemies.
I don't know exactly whatever happened between he and Reps, but they had a falling out.
And there was certain faculty that lined up with Reps and certain ones that lined up with Barkley.
When I first met Reps, I asked him if he knew Barkley.
And I had known him quite well at Berkeley before he went to Cornell.
And Rebs was very polite about it.
He said yes, he knew him.
Period.
Well, of course, Barclay was an architect.
And as I remember, at Berkeley, he gave a course in urban aesthetics, which I think was an elective course, but it was quite popular.
But all that time,
he was writing his dissertation, which was at North Carolina.
He went on in economics at North Carolina.
He got his master's in planning there.
And he went out and took that job at Berkeley and went back every summer for five years to write his dissertation.
And he finally finished it, I think, in 61.
And at that point, basically shifted either then or when he went to Cornell, which was a year or two later, shifted his orientation and put architecture all behind him and went in for economics.
Incredible.
So many people at Cornell, not knowing his background, wouldn't believe you if you said he was an architect.
Yeah, because he and Jacobs were
Doing a lot of collaborations.
Yes, and I think Jacobs went first at Cornell, I think.
And I think Barclay went a year later.
Steve died some years ago.
He was playing squash at Cornell.
OK, so then you were teaching at Cornell.
And then what happened?
I had this one-year appointment.
The professor came back, and Barclay couldn't find anything else for me.
And Roger Creighton had been trying to get me to go work for him for some time.
And he had been with me in Chicago.
Carol was the director of the Chicago study, and Roger Creighton was the assistant director.
And then later, he didn't go to New York City.
He went to upstate New York.
And he moved to Albany.
And he and John Hamburg both moved from Chicago to Albany.
And they ran the upstate New York transportation studies, the first big one in Buffalo.
And they did Rochester, Syracuse, all the cities.
And then Roger and John eventually left and started a consulting firm in Albany called Creighton Hamburg Incorporated.
And so Roger came in the middle of the year that I was teaching.
I guess that would be like in January of 72.
And he made me a firm offer for a job.
And Barclay Jones just couldn't make any commitments at Cornell.
He just didn't have a faculty line open.
And so I took the job in Albany and went off there
work half-time and write my dissertation the other half-time.
What was your dissertation topic?
Well, it's quite a mathematical study on mass transit.
It's on optimizing the design of mass transit systems.
And I worked on it five years in the end.
And it's huge.
It's over 700 pages.
It was the longest one they'd ever had at Cornell, or I think somebody's passed it since then.
David Johnson had one almost as long.
I think a fellow's at Tennessee now.
This was about 600 and some pages, I think.
So you got your PhD.
So, well, I worked...
My original arrangement was that I would work alternate weeks, but that never works out.
And I became responsible for a contract working on a transfer proposal for the west side of Manhattan.
It was part of the West Side Highway Project, which was the biggest contract that Creighton had at that time.
And it was so much pressure and all that I went a long time without working on my dissertation at all.
Sometimes I had to go to New York every day, every week for meetings and all, which was a three hour train ride each way.
But that was my really only exposure to the world of politics, although it was bureaucratic politics.
But my other jobs had been very sheltered.
They were really, even though they were with government agencies, they were really academic-type research jobs.
I never met the public or elected officials.
But my work, I have to say, that was my one consulting experience, my one real experience.
I did learn an awful lot about the real world that I didn't know about before.
But I finally came to a point where I had to decide whether I was going to finish my dissertation or forget about it.
And at one time, then, Norm offered me a job in Cleveland to be his assistant.
And then I kind of had to decide, because I knew if I took that job in Cleveland, I could forget about the dissertation.
But I turned it down.
and decided to go ahead and finish the dissertation.
And so I finally resigned from Creighton Hamburg.
And I just sort of holed up in my apartment in Albany and just worked straight through the dissertation.
Let's see, this would be in 1974.
And I guess it took about eight months, finally.
And I had to do a lot of computer runs.
So I used to run back to Cornell to use the computer there.
I usually stayed with Pierre and Ann Clavell.
And they were very generous to me through the years.
And basically, even if they went away on vacation, they let me stay in their house for a week at a time.
So finally, I completed a whole draft just before Christmas in 1974.
And then, knowing this was going to happen, I sort of looked around for a job.
because I felt I could go to work in January.
But there usually weren't very many jobs, but it just so happened that Kyle Goldschmidt was looking for a fill-in for two quarters starting in January of 75 at Michigan State.
And it was only a half-time position, teaching one course a quarter.
But it was something, it was experience, and so I
I took that position and went out and spent about six months in Lansing.
And had trouble.
I didn't get along there very well.
There were kind of these three old men on the faculty.
And actually, my line, my position was one of Myles Boylan's.
It was his line.
And he did a research grant.
And so he bought himself off.
for one semester, or two quarters.
They had a quarter system.
So I didn't really get along with Miles and the other two older faculty.
And it became obvious that I couldn't stay there.
So I went out looking for a job again.
And meanwhile, I had my dissertation hearing, and I passed that.
And I lined up a typist to type 700 pages.
But I guess I was able to, I got two job offers then from George Washington University, which is where my brother teaches, and from Texas.
And I decided to take the one in Texas.
And so I moved down to Texas in the summer of 75.
That was when John Gallery was the chair of the planning program.
From Pennsylvania.
Yeah, from the Philadelphia area.
The search committee was Jim Hotling and Sandy Rosenbloom and a student.
I went down there and they interviewed me.
I liked it quite well there, so I decided to pick that one.
Well, not only my brother, but my mother was living in the Washington area.
Very disappointed I didn't take the job at George Washington.
So I moved down, and my dissertation got finished.
The typist would mail off sections from, she was at Ithaca, would mail off chapters that she finished typing them, and then I would correct them.
Finally, at the end, about the last week, I hired a Kelly girl to work for me to finish up the corrections.
And then I finally put it together and mailed it off, and it got there on the deadline.
So I think the last day of my seven-year limit.
You had seven years to complete your work for a doctorate.
And I just made it.
This was in September of 75.
That's when my doctorate was officially awarded.
Good planning.
So that puts me in Texas.
Yes, with John Gallery and Sandy Rosenblum and so forth.
Yes, and the others in the faculty were Peter Coleman and Terry Kahn.
And my line, my position had been held by Ray Parkins, who was a black professor.
And I'm not sure when he came, I met him.
He was also, I think, a minister.
And maybe both a divinity degree and a law degree.
He was very active in the state legislature.
And I understand he had some contacts and some of the legislators and apparently got certain housing passed with regard, certain bills passed with regard to housing.

that was before i went there i don't know much about it he was offered a position at the university of tennessee and left and that created the vacancy that i feel how long were you at texas i would say six years from 75 to 1981. and then after gallery went back to philadelphia
there were some changes in the structure.
I could even go back, if you want, and tell you what I know about what was there.
Of course, the program was started by Hugo Leipziger Pierce.
Yes.
I've interviewed Hugo.
Okay, I wasn't sure whether he was still alive.
Oh, yes.
He must be in his late 80s.
He's still a very viable guy.
And Martha.
Martha, I think, was a student of his, and I believe she's quite a lot younger.
Yes.
maybe even 20 years.
I think Hugo went there either during or after World War II.
Well, I have that all documented.
You know all that.
And I think he was teaching planning courses in the architecture program.
And finally, let's see.
There's something out of one of our brochures I copied.
It says, courses in planning were offered as early as 1940.
The graduate professional degree
Master of Science Community Regional Planning was approved in 1959.
But I don't think they had any graduates for about five years.
I think the first graduate was in 64.
Basically, it was just Hugo.
But then he took on Peter Colvin.
Now, Peter Colvin was a second graduate.
He graduated in 65.
In the early years, they were graduating one student a year.
And Peter Colvin, after he left, went to the University of Kansas and taught, I think, two years in the architecture school there.
And then- Is he British?
He's from South Africa.
South Africa.
I believe his-
Undergraduate school is Witwatersrand.
It's one of the major universities in South Africa.
I've forgotten exactly when.
He may have come over to study at Texas.
That's quite possible.
He came as a foreign student.
He took this position and he taught in Lawrence, Kansas for two years.
And then Hugo apparently got authorization for another position and recruited Peter and got him to come back.
And as part of this, the inducement made him associate professor with tenure.
So he started on the faculty in that position, and he still has that.
I don't think he's ever been promoted beyond that.
Sounds like me.
Is that how you associate professor?
For 10 years.
That's all I've ever had.
Well, you've got to move, you see.
I moved to another university.
Otherwise, if I was still at Texas, I'd probably still be associate professor.
I think it was just Hugo and Peter for several years.
And then at some point, Hugo, I guess, stepped down, or maybe he retired, and Leon Cole became the chair, who had a PhD from Harvard.
And he hired several of the people.
I think he hired Terry Kahn, and I know he hired Jim Hartley and Sandy Rosenblum.
And they came at the same time, and I've forgotten.
This sort of roping, I would say maybe Terry Kahn came in 1972, and Hartley and Rosenblum came in 73, something like that.
So Leon was able to expand the program quite substantially in a short time.
Was he a planner?
He got a PhD in planning from Harvard.
He did?
Yeah.
And he must have been there about four years, something like that.
I think maybe he grew up in Texas, you know, and eventually went off to the east to be educated and then came back.
He always reminded me of sort of a power broker type.
You know him?
I met him.
I'm not sure where.
I might have met him once.
I certainly wouldn't recognize him.
I wouldn't either.
Well, he left all of a sudden in the middle of the year.
I think he didn't even wait until the end of the semester.
What was the reason?
I'm not sure it's clear.
The things I heard from the faculty about him were he was kind of a wheeler-dealer, and they never really know what was going on or what he was doing.
But apparently he was very energetic, and he got a lot of money and things.
And it built up a number of students, I think, too.
He took a position in the Library of Congress.
I think as an economist.
I think he might have had a degree in economics before he got his PhD in planning.
And he may still be there.
I really haven't heard about him for many years.
I think Peter Koltman was acting director after he left.
And I think they did a national search and they hired John Gowery.
And then, let's see, when I came there, okay, in the fall of 75, things were quite a bit of turmoil.
There was a dean there that was having a lot of trouble.
Now, he was from Philadelphia.
His name was Charles Burnett.
He might have bought a gallery.
Maybe Burnett went there first and then he kind of selected a gallery to come.
He'd known them in Philadelphia.
I think they both were... Burnett had a PhD in architecture, I think.
He was one of like 50 people in the country that had doctorates in architecture.
From Penn?
I believe that's right.
Only a few schools give it.
Berkeley gives it.
We have a doctor from Berkeley.
And this sort of came to a head right before Christmas in 1975.
And somehow the architecture faculty gave a vote of no confidence to Burnett.
And we really weren't in on this.
The planning people are pretty isolated.
But anyway, he just resigned all of a sudden, effective in two weeks or something like that.
And then Gallery was made acting dean.
He, I guess, had been given the title of associate dean before.
I think he sort of helped with some of the administrative work.
And also, he's not really trained in planning.
He's really trained as an architect.
He just sort of picked up planning through work experience and all through doing urban design projects.
So John Gallery served as the acting dean
for the spring of 76.
And of course, he didn't spend much time on the planning program, and things were pretty chaotic.
And John wanted to be the permanent dean.
But there was apparently a substantial group on the architecture faculty that didn't want him.
And eventually, they hired Hal Lox.
They hired Hal Box away from UT Arlington.
Yes, that's right.
And I understand the reason that he was hired was because he was the oldest member of the faculty at UT Arlington.
So he must have known something.
Well, he had a very successful practice in Dallas, I believe.
One of the larger firms in Dallas.
I understand he understands very little about planning.
Well, he's not an intellectual.
He's a very good fundraiser.
Most of these people, even in planning now, have titles on their names.
They're endowed.
I don't know how to get their catalog.
I mean, Sandy Rosenblum is an endowed share.
Some of them are endowed lecturers or endowed teaching fellow.
Basically, I think there's a whole system of salary supplements.
Apparently in that school, you know, over half of the faculty is some kind of endowment.
It gives them extra money.
That's nice.
And I don't know what A&M, I mean, some of all that endowment money went to A&M too, I think.
We don't have any endowed chairs.
You don't have any?
Or an architecture?
An architecture, I don't think there are any endowed chairs either.
There's only one endowed chair in the entire college.
So let's see.
Well, when Box came and Gowley realized he wasn't going to get the position, he kind of went out looking for another job and left and went to work in the city of Philadelphia for Frank Rizzo.
And so then there was an interim when Terry Kahn was made the acting director.
It may just have been one semester.
It seems to me maybe Gallery left at the end of the fall semester.
So I think that was probably the spring of 77 that Terry was acting director.
And then we did a national search for a current director.
I had some very good candidates, and I think about four or five people came to interview, and Ed McClure was selected then.
I wonder if somebody should check, I guess.
Where is Ed McClure from?
Where was he from?
I believe he's a native of Florida.
I believe he grew up in Florida.
And I think he was talking about visiting his father.
And he had started two planning programs.
He got his PhD at Harvard in planning.
after many, many years.
But he started the program at VPI, which they now call Virginia Tech.
He was the first chair of that.
And then he started the program at Florida State.
At Calhoun State?
Yeah.
He was the originator of that program.
Also, he's a very important person in the history of planning, really, of planning education.
Can I repeat that?
No, it's over.
Okay, while Ed was in Texas, he was asked to run for president of the Association of Collegiate Schools of Planning.
And he decided to and was elected and really changed that whole organization.
He was most of the presidents and then kind of caretakers.
that hadn't really pushed very much.
But he had a definite platform, which he was able to get through.
Two main things he wanted.
He wanted to have separate conferences from the professionals.
He thought they really got kind of pushed aside by the American Planning Association as a predecessor now.
And the other thing is he wanted to have a journal, not just a newsletter, but a journal for planning education.
And both of those things were accomplished while he was president and all, and both of them really have been quite successful.
Oh, yeah, the journal is really a very high-quality publication.
Well, some other people, you know, said, well, you know, we're just not going to have something that talks about how to teach.
You know, research is important, too.
Pierre Clavel was one of these.
He, at one time, was very active.
And he said, you know, it's going to be research as well as teaching.
You know, that's the way it's turned out.
And the conferences are quite successful too.
I've never, for one reason or another, I haven't attended them, except I think one, but usually our department had those.
Right.
Okay, so I don't know, let's see, are there other people on the faculty?
What about the program itself?
What kind of curriculum does the program have or did it have?
Has it gone through many changes through the year?
There was one major change after McClure came.
There may have been some earlier too, probably before I got there in 1975.
